Inspire me in this taske (JHOVES seede I pray)</br>With Hippocrenes drops besprinke my head,</br>To comfort me upon this tedious way,</br>And quicken my cold braine nigh dull and dead;</br>Direct my wandring spirits, when they stray,</br>Least forren and forbidden paths they tread:</br>My journey's tedious, (blame not then my feares)</br>My voyage, aymes at many thousand yeares.

Oh give me leave, from the Worlds first Creation,</br>The ancient names of Britons, to derive</br>From Adam, to the Worlds first Inundation,</br>And so from Noah, to us that yet survive:</br>And having of Troyes Worthies made relation,</br>Your spurs the Chariot of my Muse must drive</br>Through all past Ages, and precedent times,</br>To fill this new World with my worthlesse rymes.

Oh, may these Artlesse numbers in your eares,</br>(Renowmed JAMES) seeme Musically strung,</br>Your fame (oh JOVES-star'd Prince) spread every where,</br>First gave my still and speech-lesse Muse a tung:</br>From your Majestike vertues (prised deare,)</br>The infant life of these harsh meeters sprung;</br>Oh, take not then their industrie in skorne,</br>Who, but to emblaze you, had beene yet unborne.

Not let your Princely Peeres hold in disdaine,</br>To have their Auncestry stild'e and inrolde</br>In this poore Register, a higher straine</br>Their merits aske, since brazen leaves unfold</br>Their never-dying Fame, yet thus much daine,</br>Not to despise to heare your vertues told</br>In a plaine stile, by one, whose wish and hart,</br>Supplies in zeale, want both of Skill and Art.

Times faithfully conferd, the first invention</br>Of most thinges now in use, heare you shall finde,</br>Annext with these, the use and comprehention</br>Of Poesie, once to the Goddes desceind,</br>Suffer our bluntnesse then, since our intention</br>Is to good use, sent from a zealous mind.</br>If Stones in Lead set, keepe their vertues:  then,</br>Your worth's the same, though blazde by a rude Pen.</br>
